articles.title: About this site
articles.contents:
This site was built by Hannah Koenker, Technical Director at Tropical Health. Both Stata and R were used for analysis and presentation of the findings.

Methods

Publicly available datasets were downloaded from dhsprogram.com and mics.unicef.org. Appropriate survey weights were applied using the “svy” command in Stata and the “survey” package in R. Regression results for the maps on the homepage were run with the svy: logistic command in Stata; those in the reports were run with the svyglm command in R, using a quasi-binomial specification.

articles.title: ITN Textile vs ITN Use
articles.description:
Does the textile of an ITN make a difference in the overall use rate?
Last update: `r format(Sys.time(), '%d %B, %Y')`
articles.contents:
This website provides reports for countries in sub-Saharan Africa to evaluate whether there are differences in use of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) due to the textile of ITNs (i.e. polyester or polyethylene).
Some countries may wish to procure ITNs of a particular textile. These reports use large household survey data to evaluate whether there are differences in use between polyester and polyethylene nets in a particular country, and whether net textile is associated with these differences after controlling for other determinants of net use.
These reports walk through several key questions to ask as we consider this question and provide recommendations for next steps.
This work is supported by the Alliance for Malaria Prevention with funding from The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.










Summary

Data from the most recent MIS, DHS, and MICS were obtained with permission from dhsprogram.com and mics.unicef.org. We plot several maps below of relevant indicators. Figure 1 presents the crude (absolute) difference between the proportion of polyester nets used the previous night and the proportion of polyethylene nets used the previous night. In nearly all cases this difference is less than 10 percentage points and the majority of recent surveys show no significant difference in the overall use rate of nets of different textiles.



Figure 1: Crude difference in % of nets used between textiles



Figure 2 summarizes countries where the most recent survey shows a correlation between the textile of a net and whether it was used the previous night. In most countries, textile is not significantly correlated with use when controlling for other factors.



Figure 2: Correlation of textile with use: adjusted for household supply of nets, net age, region, wealth, urban/rural, net age, and month



The textile is determined from the brand information collected in the survey; in some surveys the proportion of nets with an unknown brand can be considerable. Figure 3 summarizes the proportion of nets with an unknown brand and thus an unknown textile. This provides important context when interpreting results above.



Figure 3: Proportion of nets with unknown brand & textile



Figure 4 illustrates the distribution of textiles within countries - darker reds indicate a high proportion of polyethylene nets, and darker blues indicate majority polyester nets at the time of the most recent survey.



Figure 4: Proportion of nets that are polyester
















Meta analysis across multiple surveys and countries




Figure 5: Forest Plot summarizing odds of a PE net being used; most recent survey per country
